My Dear Milton;

You should know about crappy tsuba.  
You have cornered the market and made a study of them over the past 5 years.  

Isn't it time you moved onto at least mediocre tsuba and fittings?  

Even the Ferengi appreciate beauty, even if it is at the most basic level.

Have a Merry Christmas,

John
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: bungotakadasword 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 3:50 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Where do you buy your Tsuba?


  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Kenneth Wilson <kdw21620@y...> 
  wrote:
  >

  > Milt I think took his love of hawk paintings and that
  > transferred over into his tsuba collection, although,
  > he doesn't stick to just that motif.  
  >

  I collect the " designs " that strike me.......I don't care what 
  school, material, and I like to buy them " cheap " like a Ferengi so 
  at least i have a fair chance to get my $ back or even make 10 bucks 
  or so when I get tired of some of them.


  >  I would love to
  > sit down with someone more knowledgeable and be shown
  > iron quality.  Jim G. said all it takes is handling a
  > few thousand tsuba.  
  > 
  > 
  > 
  > All you have to do is buy one or two really crappy iron tsuba, then 
  you will know what " good " iron feels/look like.  See ? craps can 
  teach you something.........

  Milt
  >
